mainmatter.p: A useful property of categorical constructions is the immediately available dual interpretation. It corresponds to the \mathcal{C} ^{op} category associated with \mathcal{C}, where the following happens:
mainmatter.ol:
\mathcal{C} ^{op}-objects are the same as \mathcal{C}-objects.
Given the arrows in \mathcal{C}, such as f: A \rightarrow B, the \mathcal{C} ^{op} will have the source and target swapped, such as f^{op}: B \rightarrow A
The identity arrows are preserved the same, 1_A^{op} = 1_A
Composition also has the source and target swapped, such that f \circ ^{op} g = g \circ fThis way of constructing categories allows us to have "free proofs", from whatever categorical concept.
